lead.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to take someone somewhere by going in front of them while they follow, or by pulling them gently
lead.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The manager led the way through the office.
A nurse took her arm and led her to a chair.
The horses were led to safety.
She was led away from the courtroom in tears.
lead.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to go in front of a line of people or vehicles
lead.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: A firetruck was leading the parade.
lead.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to be in charge of an organization, country, or team, or a group of people who are trying to do something
lead.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He has led the party for over twenty years.
Some people say she is too old to lead the country (=be in charge of its government).
Beckham led his team to victory.
a man who was born to lead
The investigation will be led by Inspector Scarfe.
They are leading a campaign to warn teenagers about the dangers of drug abuse.
The rebellion was led by the King’s brother.
Nelson preferred to lead the attack himself from the front.
lead.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to cause something to happen or cause someone to do something
lead.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: the events that led to the start of the First World War
A degree in English could lead to a career in journalism.
Her trusting nature often led her into trouble.
What led him to kill his wife?
His actions could lead to him losing his job.
lead.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to make someone believe something, especially something that is not true
lead.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Our research led us to the conclusion that the present system is unfair.
He had led everyone to believe that his family was very wealthy.
The hotel was terrible, and not at all what we had been led to expect.
lead.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to influence someone to make them do something that is wrong
lead.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: He’s not a bad boy. He’s just easily led (=it is easy for other people to persuade him to do things that he should not do).
His brother led him into a life of crime.
lead.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to be more successful than other people, companies, or countries in a particular activity
lead.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: US companies lead the world in biotechnology.
The Swedes have led the way in data protection.
lead.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to be winning a game, competition etc
lead.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: With 15 laps to go, Schumacher led the race.
The polls showed Obama leading Romney by 3 percent.
Nadal was leading by two sets.
lead by ten points/two goals etc
lead.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: used to say where a path, wire etc goes or what place is on the other side of a door
lead.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: The path led down to a small lake.
the major artery leading from the heart
the door leading into the hallway
The riverside path leads visitors to a small chapel.
lead.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if you lead a particular kind of life, that is what your life is like
lead a life of luxury/poverty etc
lead.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: If the operation succeeds, Carly will be able to lead a normal life.
He has led a charmed life (=been very fortunate).
She now leads the life of a recluse.
Joe had been leading a double life, seeing an ex-model while his wife believed he was on business.
lead.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to control the way a discussion, conversation etc develops
lead.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: I tried to lead the conversation back to the subject of money.
lead.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to play a particular card as your first card in one part of a card game
lead.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: lead
to take a person or animal somewhere by going in front of them while they follow, or by pulling them gently
Rachel led Jo into the kitchen.
She was leading a horse, which seemed to have a bad leg.
to take someone somewhere with you when you have the transport, know the way, are paying etc
I took her to see a film.
Matt’s taking me in his car.
guide
to take someone through or to a place you know, showing them the way
Ali guided us through the streets to his house on the edge of the town.
to take someone to a place such as a table in a restaurant or a hotel room and leave them there
A waitress showed us to our table.
We were shown to our seats near the front of the theatre.
to show someone which direction to go using your hand or a sign
The sign back there pointed this way.
escort
to take someone somewhere, protecting them, guarding them, or showing them the way
He was escorted from the court by police.
The president’s car will be escorted by a military convoy.
usher
to show someone the way to a room or building nearby, usually as part of your job
His housekeeper ushered us into the living room.
shepherd
to carefully take someone somewhere – used especially about a group of people
The police shepherded thousands of people to safety in the cathedral.
to tell someone where to go or how to get somewhere
He directed us to a café a few blocks away.
Can you direct me to the station?
lead.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the amount or distance by which one competitor is ahead of another
lead.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The Chicago Bulls had a narrow lead (=were winning by a small number of points).
The Socialists now have a commanding lead over their opponents.
lead.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if someone follows someone else’s lead, they do the same as the other person has done
lead.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Other countries are likely to follow the U.S.'s lead.
The Government should give industry a lead in tackling racism  (=show what other people should do).
The black population in the 1960s looked to Ali for a lead (=looked to him to show them what they should do).
lead.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a piece of information that may help you to solve a crime or mystery
lead.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The police have checked out dozens of leads, but have yet to find the killer.
lead.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: the main acting part in a play, film etc, or the main actor
lead.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Powers was cast in the lead role (=he was chosen to play it).
He will play the lead role in ‘Hamlet’.
They were having trouble casting the female lead.
lead.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a piece of rope, leather, or chain for holding or controlling a dog
lead.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: All dogs must be kept on a lead.
lead.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a wire used to connect a piece of electrical equipment to the power supply
lead.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: He was in the lead after the first lap of the race.
He has a one-shot lead in the golf tournament.
Lewis Hamilton has just taken the lead in the Monaco Grand Prix.
Ronaldo’s goal put Portugal in the lead.
A goal in the 10th minute gave England the lead.
The Australian rugby team extended its lead with a try from Stirling Mortlock.
Arsenal threw away a two-goal lead.
They managed to blow a 22-point lead.
At the end of the first round, two golfers share the lead.
The Bruins had a big lead at half-time.
The ruling Labour Party has a clear lead in the opinion polls.
The Wildcats had a comfortable lead in the first half.
Alonso raced into a commanding lead.
Liverpool took an early lead with a goal from Steven Gerrard.
Goals by Keane and Lennon gave Tottenham a two-goal lead.
lead.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a soft heavy grey metal that melts easily and is poisonous, used on roofs, or in the past for water pipes. It is a chemical element: symbol Pb
lead.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the central part of a pencil that makes the marks when you write
lead.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: They filled him full of lead.
lead.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to be in charge of something such as an important activity, a group of people, or an organization
lead.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The manager had led a series of projects that improved productivity in his region.
a new management team led by Roger Shute
lead.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to be more successful than other people, companies, or countries in a particular activity or area of business
lead.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Printing banknotes is one area where Britain leads the world.
a company that leads the field in software applications
lead.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: Typically, stockmarkets lead the recovery of the real economy by four to six months.
lead.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: to be the first to do something, especially something good or successful, which is likely to encourage others to do the same thing
lead.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: Large grocery multiples and the oil companies have led the way in retail modelling.
lead.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: a piece of information such as a list of telephone numbers that may help someone selling something to find customers
lead.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: The in-house sales team deals with all telephone sales leads.
lead.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: when you are in front of or better than everyone else you are competing with
lead.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: The company has a substantial lead over its main competitors.
